content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is an example function that meets your requirements:
```julia
function audi_filter(df_cars)
    df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi", df_cars)
    df = filter(row -> row.model in ["a4", "a4 quattro"], df)
    df["audi_a4_type"] = true
    return df
end
```
This function first filters the `df_cars` DataFrame to only include rows with the manufacturer "audi". It then filters this subset of data to only include rows with a model that is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". Finally, it adds a new column called "audi_a4_type" which is set to `true` across all rows. The resulting DataFrame is returned.

You can use this function as follows:
```julia
df = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
